questions.question: What is the primary principle that governs the process of sedimentation in water treatment?

answerOptions.text: Chemical reaction
Biological absorption
Gravity
Adsorption

questions.question: In the context of sedimentation, what defines Type I, or discrete particle, settling?

answerOptions.text: Particles aggregate and increase in size as they settle.
Particles settle at a constant velocity without interacting with each other.
Settling is hindered by high concentrations of particles.
Particles settle due to compression of the particle structure.

questions.question: Which design parameter is considered the most critical for determining the removal efficiency of discrete particles in an ideal sedimentation tank?

answerOptions.text: Tank depth
Detention time
Surface Overflow Rate (SOR)
Length to width ratio

questions.question: According to Stokes' Law for discrete particle settling, if the diameter of a spherical particle is doubled, how does its terminal settling velocity change, assuming all other factors remain constant?

answerOptions.text: It remains the same.
It doubles.
It increases by a factor of four.
It decreases by half.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the coagulation and flocculation processes that precede sedimentation?

answerOptions.text: To disinfect the water by killing pathogens.
To convert very small, non-settleable particles into larger, settleable flocs.
To remove dissolved minerals like calcium and magnesium.
To adjust the pH of the water to make it less corrosive.

questions.question: In a sedimentation tank, 'short-circuiting' is a condition that adversely affects performance. What does this term mean?

answerOptions.text: The tank overflows due to excessive inlet flow.
Water flows through the tank faster than the theoretical detention time.
The sludge removal mechanism gets stuck.
The flow is perfectly uniform throughout the tank's cross-section.

questions.question: How does an increase in water temperature typically affect the efficiency of sedimentation?

answerOptions.text: It decreases efficiency because particles become more buoyant.
It has no effect on sedimentation efficiency.
It increases efficiency because it reduces the viscosity of water.
It decreases efficiency by promoting algae growth in the tank.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the inlet zone in a sedimentation tank?

answerOptions.text: To collect the settled sludge for removal.
To provide a final polishing of the water before it exits.
To ensure quiescent conditions for particle settling.
To distribute the incoming flow uniformly and dissipate its energy.

questions.question: A particle will be 100% removed in an ideal horizontal flow sedimentation tank if its individual settling velocity (Vs) is:

answerOptions.text: Less than the surface overflow rate (Vo).
Equal to or greater than the surface overflow rate (Vo).
Equal to the horizontal flow-through velocity.
Less than the scour velocity.

questions.question: What is the main difference between Type I (discrete) settling and Type II (flocculant) settling?

answerOptions.text: Type I occurs in circular tanks, while Type II occurs in rectangular tanks.
Type I involves sand and grit, while Type II involves organic solids.
In Type II settling, particles aggregate and their settling velocity increases as they fall.
Type I settling is temperature-dependent, while Type II is not.

questions.question: The theoretical detention time in a sedimentation tank is calculated by which formula?

answerOptions.text: Tank Area / Flow Rate
Flow Rate / Tank Surface Area
Tank Volume / Flow Rate
Tank Length / Horizontal Velocity

questions.question: Stokes' Law is most accurate for describing the settling of particles under which conditions?

answerOptions.text: Turbulent flow around large, irregular particles.
Laminar flow around small, spherical particles.
High solids concentrations where particles interfere with each other.
Flocculating particles that are increasing in size.

questions.question: What is the purpose of weir troughs placed at the outlet of a sedimentation tank?

answerOptions.text: To add chemicals for disinfection.
To skim floating scum from the water surface.
To ensure the horizontal velocity is high enough to prevent settling in the trough.
To collect the clarified water uniformly across the tank's width with minimal turbulence.

questions.question: The resuspension of already settled particles due to high horizontal flow velocity is known as:

answerOptions.text: Flocculation
Short-circuiting
Scour
Hindered settling

questions.question: Why is sedimentation considered a crucial step before filtration in a conventional water treatment plant?

answerOptions.text: It removes dissolved solids that would pass through filters.
It significantly reduces the load of suspended solids going to the filters.
It adds a protective layer of sludge onto the filter media.
It is the primary step for pathogen removal.
